References Created by Moving Objects

When a folder or item is moved from one location to another within the same view, the object is deleted at the original location and placed in the new location. Moving objects may cause unexpected side effects in the view's parent and children, however, if any of these views float. The reason is that the copy of the folder or item at the original location is not deleted, except in the current view. Therefore, the parent and child views may end up with two references (one to the old location and one to the new location), instead of a single reference to a new location.

Floating Upwards and Downwards

If the view hierarchy is deep (the root view has grandchildren, great-grandchildren and so on), the use of branching, floating views can cause a great deal of confusion. Suppose all views except the root view can branch and float. At its new location, depending on how the views were created, the folder or item you have moved can float:

  • Up the view hierarchy from the recipient view to the root view.

  • Down to all of recipient view’s children, grandchildren, and so on.

  • From the recipient view’s parents, grandparents, and so on, to all of their other children.

A move operation produces one less reference to the moved folder or item in the view from which it was moved, and one more reference to it in the recipient view.
